consider.translation[0].definitions[0].d: to think about something carefully, especially before making a choice or decision
consider.translation[0].definitions[0].n: be considering your position formal (=be deciding whether or not to leave your job)
consider.translation[0].definitions[0].e: We will have to consider your offer carefully.
Have you considered the possibility of retraining?
I seriously considered resigning  (=almost actually resigned).
We are considering whether to change our advice to tourists.
We’re still considering where to move to.
consider.translation[0].definitions[0].n: Consider is followed by an -ing form, not an infinitive You consider doing something
I considered asking for my money back
I considered to ask for my money back
consider.translation[0].definitions[1].d: to think of someone or something in a particular way or to have a particular opinion
consider.translation[0].definitions[1].e: I did not consider it necessary to report the incident.
consider it necessary/important etc to do something
I consider it a great honour to be invited.
consider it necessary/important etc to do something
Consider yourself lucky you weren’t in the car at the time.
The local authority considered that the school did not meet requirements.
A further increase in interest rates is now considered unlikely.
Liz Quinn was considered an excellent teacher.
They consider themselves to be Europeans.
The campaign was considered to have failed.
They consider themselves to be middle class.
consider.translation[0].definitions[2].d: to think about someone or their feelings, and try to avoid upsetting them
consider.translation[0].definitions[2].e: You’ve got to learn to consider other people!
consider.translation[0].definitions[3].d: to think about an important fact relating to something when making a judgment
consider.translation[0].definitions[3].e: It’s not surprising when you consider that he only arrived six months ago.
All things considered, I’m sure we made the right decision.
consider.translation[0].definitions[4].d: to discuss something such as a report or problem, so that you can make a decision about it
consider.translation[0].definitions[4].e: The committee has been considering the report.
consider.translation[0].definitions[5].d: to look at someone or something carefully
consider.translation[0].definitions[5].e: Ben considered the statue with an expert eye.
consider.translation[0].note_box[0].item: In meaning 1, consider is often used in the progressive You say
I am considering investing some money  (=I am thinking about it and may do it)
In meaning 2, consider is not used in the progressive You say
I consider it a good investment  (=I believe that it is)
I am considering it a good investment
consider.translation[0].note_box[1].sect: to have an opinion about someone or something after thinking carefully about them
We do not consider this film suitable for young children.
She is considered to be one of the finest pianists of her generation.
to think about someone or something in a particular way, or as being a particular kind of person or thing
Having a child makes you see things differently.
America was seen as the land of opportunity.
The country sees itself as a bridge between East and West.
regard/view
to think about someone or something in a particular way, or as being a particular kind of person or thing. Regard/view are a little more formal than see
She regards herself more as an entertainer than a singer.
Many people in the industry viewed him with suspicion.
perceive
to think about someone or something in a particular way, or as being a particular kind of person or thing
Historically, nursing has been perceived as a job for women, but things have changed now.
The group were perceived to have little real talent.
Do other people perceive us as we perceive ourselves?
think of somebody/something as
to think that someone or something is a particular type of person or thing
He looked on his job as a welcome relief from the problems at home.
Even though he’s 18, his parents still think of him as a child.
I think of her more as a sister.
